Subject: Re[2]: [junit] how many tests on a method - all possible scenarios

>> To me, one of the benefits of tests is that they help me to spot design
>> problems early. Whenever I find it difficult to write a test for a
method,
KOS> I
>> ask myself whether it's the method's fault.

KOS>     As a newbie to junit I'm still trying to understand how to judge if
when
KOS> its 'difficult' to write a test for a method. My question was sparked
KOS> because I was in what I would call a laborous position - multiple code
paths
KOS> so multiple test cases. I had 30 test cases for one method, amounting
to 300
KOS> lines of code. Is this tedious or difficult. In JUnit world, does
tedious ==
KOS> difficult?

Yes, it does.  Quick question.  How many lines does that method have?
